_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Hisco, Inc. (Hisco) owns and operates a warehouse and distribution facility in the City of Austin, Travis County, Texas. Hisco has reviewed its obligations under EPA?s Risk Management Program Rule (RMP Rule, Section 112? of the Clean Air Act).  In response to these requirements, Hisco notes that there are two obligations incumbent on the operations at its facility:

1. ?112?(1) - Purpose and General Duty Clause - The essence of the general duty clause is that an owner/operator that stores and uses hazardous chemicals in any quantity has a fundamental obligation to ensure a safe operation, and to have plans in place in the event of an accident to appropriately manage the situation.  Hisco takes this obligation very seriously, and intends to be not only a good neighbor but also a leader in community safety and emergency preparedness.

2. Risk Management Plan ? Hisco stores ammonium hydroxide, which contains ammonia in excess of thresholds specified in ?112?. Even prior to the promulgation of the RMP Rule, Hisco management was very aware of the potential hazards posed by the storage of ammonium hydroxide, and  established programs to prevent any accidental releases and training for emergency response in the event of a release.  These programs are documented and described in this Risk Management Plan.

Chemicals are stored at Hisco prior to being distributed to other companies.  Ammonium hydroxide is delivered as a liquid in 55-gallon drums. There are approximately 160 drums of ammonium hydroxide, which amounts to approximately 38,000 pounds of ammonia, at the facility at any one time. Hydrochloric acid is delivered as a liquid in 55 gallon drum. There are approximatley 130 drums of hydrochloric acid, which is approximately 46,000 lbs of hydrochloric acid at the facility at any one time.

In the past five years, Hisco has not experienced any accidents involving an RMP chemical at its facility. For planning purposes, Hisco has considered a very conservative (i.e., ?worst
